text: CANADA — VISA / TEMPORARY RESIDENT (VISITOR) GUIDELINES (FULL TEXT) Purpose Guidance for applying for a Temporary Resident Visa (Visitor Visa) to Canada, covering who must apply, eligibility, documentation and procedural steps for visa officers and applicants. Eligibility Criteria Applicant must have a valid travel document (passport) and must be admissible to Canada. Applicant must satisfy the visa officer that they will leave Canada at the end of their authorized stay. Applicant must have sufficient funds to support themselves and any dependents during the visit (unless sponsored). Applicant must have no criminal inadmissibility issues and meet health requirements as applicable. Applicant must demonstrate ties to their home country (employment, family, property, studies) to establish intention to return. Documents Typically Required Completed application forms and instruction guide (Instruction Guide — Guide 5256 for visitor visa). Valid passport, photographs per specification, and application fees. Proof of funds (bank statements, sponsor letters). Travel itinerary, invitation letters, and any documents establishing purpose of visit. Police certificates or medical exam if requested. Notes and Special Cases Processing may vary by visa office; applicants applying on paper should consult instruction guides specific to their country. Biometric collection may be required. Electronic travel authorization rules and exemptions apply for certain nationalities; always check up-to-date IRCC pages. Key official guidance (source) IRCC: Guide 5256 — Applying for a visitor visa (Temporary Resident Visa)

Ireland’s visa policy Ireland distinguishes between short‑stay visas (type C, up to 90 days) and long‑stay visas (type D, more than 90 days) for non‑EU/EEA/Swiss and non‑UK nationals. Visa‑exempt nationals (for example many Annex II countries, US, etc.) can enter without a visa for short visits but must still respect immigration permission conditions at the border. Ireland is not part of Schengen; a Schengen visa does not allow entry to Ireland, and an Irish visa does not allow entry to Schengen countries. Who needs a visa Citizens of EU/EEA, Switzerland and the UK do not need a visa to enter Ireland, though they may still need to register for residence depending on length and purpose of stay. Many non‑EU countries are visa‑exempt for short stays, but large groups (including India, Pakistan, Nigeria, etc.) must obtain a visa even for tourism or short visits. Some nationalities are exempt from visa fees but not from the visa requirement itself. Short stay “C” visa (≤90 days) The standard short‑stay “C” visa covers tourism, visiting family/friends, business, short training or study (e.g., short English courses) for a maximum of 90 days. Applicants must show a valid reason for travel, proof of accommodation, full travel itinerary, travel/medical insurance, and sufficient funds without recourse to public funds. A key requirement is evidence of strong ties (family, social, economic) to the country of residence to show you will leave Ireland before your permission expires. Long stay “D” visa (>90 days) A long‑stay “D” visa is needed if you intend to study, work, join family, or otherwise remain in Ireland for more than 90 days. After arrival with a D visa, you must register locally with Immigration Service Delivery (ISD) or GNIB to get an Irish Residence Permit (IRP) and an immigration stamp (e.g., Stamp 1, 2, 3, 4) that defines your rights to work, study, or access services. Different D‑visa categories (study, employment, family reunification, research, etc.) have tailored document and financial requirements. Student visa policies (including 2025 fund change) For long‑term study, you apply for a long‑term study D visa with a letter of acceptance from a recognised institution, proof of tuition payment (often full or at least €6,000), English‑language test scores, medical insurance, and explanations of study and career plans. From mid‑2025, financial requirements increased: students generally must now show at least about €12,000 in liquid, traceable funds for living costs, up from €10,000 under previous rules. Indian and other non‑EU students on a valid student permission can usually work part‑time during term and full‑time during scheduled breaks, and may access post‑study work routes (typically 1–2 years) before moving to an employment permit if eligible. Work and employment‑related policies Non‑EU nationals usually need an employment permit (e.g., Critical Skills or General Employment Permit) plus a corresponding D visa before travelling to take up work. Policy updates up to 2025 have expanded the list of eligible occupations (e.g., some social care and technical trades) and reduced the minimum period before changing employers from 12 to 9 months for first‑time permit holders. Spouses and partners of certain permit holders now have broader rights to work without their own employment permit, although some dependants must wait 12 months before relocating and others receive non‑work Stamp 3 permission. Visit, processing times, and documentation Tourist/visitor C visas typically require a completed online application, passport valid at least 6 months beyond intended stay, photos, fee payment, proof of funds, accommodation, travel plans, and letters explaining purpose and intention to return. Typical processing times for C tourist visas are in the range of about 15–25 working days, but can be longer if extra checks are needed or during busy seasons. Official ISD tables regularly publish which application dates are currently being processed for different visa types (tourism, study, employment, etc.), useful for planning. Immigration permission stamps and residence After entry, your passport is stamped with an immigration permission type (Stamp 1 for most workers, Stamp 2 for full‑time students, Stamp 3 for non‑working dependants, Stamp 4 for certain long‑term residents and family members, etc.). These stamps, plus the Irish Residence Permit card, govern what you can legally do in Ireland: work, study, start a business, or simply reside without work rights. Extensions or changes of status usually require applying to ISD with updated documents before your current permission expires.

Schengen visa rules allow stays of up to 90 days in any 180-day period across the 29 Schengen Area member states. Applicants must submit an application form, valid passport, ICAO- compliant photos, medical travel insurance, and proof of purpose, financial means, accommodation, and intention to return. Entry into the Schengen Area starts a 180-day counter, and overstaying is not allowed. The visa sticker specifies permitted days. Key Rules Visa validity: Maximum 90 days within any 180-day period; applies to the entire Schengen Area, not per country. Passport validity: Must be valid for at least 3 months beyond intended departure. Entry types: Single-entry: one entry only. Multiple-entry: repeated entries allowed, but stays must follow the 90/180 rule. Competent authority: Apply to the embassy/consulate of your main destination or the first- entry country if no main destination. Required Documents Completed Schengen visa application form Valid passport with minimum three months validity beyond departure date ICAO-standard passport photos Proof of Schengen medical travel insurance (covers medical emergencies, hospitalization, repatriation; minimum €30,000) Supporting documents for purpose of stay: Flight bookings Hotel bookings or accommodation proof Bank statements, payslips Proof of financial means Cover letter explaining purpose Evidence of intention to return Fingerprints are collected unless exempt Recent Changes for Indian Nationals Eligibility for 2-year multiple-entry visa requires at least two previously used Schengen visas in the last three years. After using a 2-year MEV, eligibility may extend to a 5-year multiple-entry visa. Visa validity cannot exceed passport expiry. Schengen Travel Rules (Dos) 1. Ensure proper validity Visa stays max 90 days in 180 days; cannot be exceeded. Invalid visa can lead to penalties or bans. 2. Carry essential documents Passport, insurance, accommodation proof, return ticket, and other required docs must be carried. 3. Respect local customs Understand local traditions; behave accordingly. Schengen Travel Rules (Don’ts) 1. Don’t ignore travel insurance Mandatory; minimum €30,000 coverage for emergencies. 2. Avoid overstaying Overstaying can result in deportation or legal consequences. 3. Don’t carry prohibited items Must follow each country’s customs regulations. New Visa Rules Summary Indians can receive 2-year Schengen visas. This can extend to 5-year multiple-entry visas. Allows multiple entries without needing new visas as long as passport validity supports it. FAQ Extract What is a Schengen visa? Allows travel across 29 Schengen countries with one visa. Meaning of first point of entry? The first Schengen country you will enter; responsible for issuing visa if it’s your main entry. How to apply? Apply at the relevant consulate or online; travel brokers can assist.

UNITED KINGDOM — VISA ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES (FULL TEXT) Purpose This guidance covers short-term and standard visitor visas and explains the eligibility and suitability criteria UK Visas and Immigration uses when deciding applications. It also includes permitted activities, validity and evidentiary expectations. Eligibility Criteria Applicant must intend to visit the UK for a temporary period and leave at the end of the visit. Applicant must be able to do only permitted activities for that visa class (e.g., tourism, visiting, short business activities) and must not do work or study beyond what is permitted. Applicant must pay for their return or onward journey or demonstrate funds to do so. Applicant must be able to support and accommodate themselves for the duration of their stay without accessing public funds. Applicant must satisfy identity, suitability, and credibility checks — including whether they have previously breached UK immigration rules or been removed. Applicants who require a visa must apply online and attend a biometric appointment at a visa application centre. Documents Typically Required Valid passport (with sufficient validity) and previous passports if available. Completed online application and confirmation. Biometric enrolment (photo + fingerprints) at the visa centre. Proof of travel plans and funds: bank statements, payslips, sponsorship letters, accommodation details. Evidence of ties to home country: employment letter, family, property or study enrolment. Additional documents for specific visitor subcategories (eg academic visitor evidence, medical treatment letters, etc.). Notes and Special Cases There are several distinct visitor subcategories (Standard Visitor, Transit Visitor, Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor, Academic Visitor) each with specific permitted activities and time limits. A visa does not guarantee entry — final admission is subject to border control. Some nationalities are visa-exempt; check nationality tables for requirements. Key official guidance (source) UK Visit guidance (Home Office).

�� UNITED STATES VISA ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES (TEXT VERSION) 1. VISITOR VISA (B-1 / B-2 / B-1/B-2) Purpose: Short visits for business (B-1), tourism/medical/family (B-2), or both (B-1/B-2 combined). Eligibility Criteria: Applicant’s visit must be temporary (typically under 6 months). Applicant must have a residence outside the U.S. they do not intend to abandon. Must demonstrate ties to home country (employment, family, property, etc.). Must show financial ability to cover expenses during stay. Cannot seek or accept employment in the U.S. Must have a valid passport (generally 6 months beyond intended stay). Must not have violated U.S. immigration laws previously. Documents Required: DS-160 confirmation page MRV (visa) fee receipt Interview appointment confirmation Passport-sized photo Supporting evidence (bank statements, job letters, etc.) 2. STUDENT VISAS (F-1, M-1, J-1) Purpose: For studying at approved U.S. institutions (academic, vocational, or exchange programs). Eligibility Criteria: Must have a Form I-20 (F/M) or DS-2019 (J) from a SEVP-approved institution. Must show proof of financial resources to cover tuition and living costs. Must have sufficient English proficiency or enroll in English training. Must maintain a residence abroad with no intention of permanent immigration. Must intend to study full-time at the institution. Notes: Dependents (spouse/children) can apply for F-2 / M-2 / J-2 visas. J-1 may include exchange categories like scholars, researchers, or interns. 3. WORK VISAS (H-1B, L-1, O-1, TN, etc.) H-1B (Specialty Occupations) Job must require specialized knowledge (usually bachelor’s degree or higher). Employer must file a Labor Condition Application (LCA) with the Dept. of Labor. Applicant must have the necessary qualifications and degree equivalence. L-1 (Intra-company Transfer) Applicant must have worked 1+ year abroad for a qualifying employer. Transfer must be to a parent, branch, affiliate, or subsidiary in the U.S. O-1 (Individuals with Extraordinary Ability) Must demonstrate national/international recognition in science, art, business, athletics, etc. TN (USMCA/NAFTA) For citizens of Canada or Mexico with qualifying professional occupations. 4. IMMIGRANT VISAS (Green Card Pathways) Common Categories: Family-based: Immediate relatives of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents. Employment-based: Skilled workers, professionals, investors (EB-1 to EB-5). Diversity Visa (DV Lottery): Randomly selected individuals from underrepresented countries. Eligibility Factors: Valid petition (Form I-130, I-140, etc.) approved by USCIS. No disqualifying criminal or immigration violations. Medical examination clearance. Proof of financial sponsorship (Form I-864 for family-based). 5. VISA WAIVER PROGRAM (VWP) For: Nationals of 40+ approved countries. Duration: 90 days or less (tourism/business only). Requirements: Must have ESTA authorization prior to travel. Must hold e-passport valid for at least six months beyond intended stay. No prior visa overstays or ineligibility grounds. 6. GENERAL INELIGIBILITY GROUNDS (Section 212 INA) Applicants are ineligible if they: Have overstayed or violated prior U.S. visa terms. Have certain criminal convictions (drug, moral turpitude, etc.). Pose security, health, or public charge risks. Have engaged in immigration fraud or misrepresentation . 7. KEY REFERENCES USCIS Policy Manual – Volume 2: Nonimmigrants U.S. Department of State – Visa Types Overview [8 U.S.C. §1182 (INA §212)] – Inadmissibility Criteria
